Award.AwardTitle: NRT-IGE: Information Infrastructure for Society: Integrating Data Science and Social Science in Graduate Education and Workforce Development

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (NRT) award in the Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) Track to the University of Maryland will pilot an innovative, cross-disciplinary curriculum that integrates Data Science with Social Science. The project will advance the scientific understanding of the dynamics of human behavior by integrating the toolkits and analytical frameworks developed by social scientists with the new types of data, models and tools developed in the fields of computer science and statistics. The curriculum provides an innovative approach to training students in the creative and scientific use of the growing number of available data. It covers all phases of a research project, addressing social issues including problem formulation, data collection, manipulation, processing, and analysis. The project pilots an innovative modular training program that is tailored to fill specific needs of both traditional and nontraditional graduate students, and provides direct pathways both to future employers and to advancement with current employers.

The project advances the understanding of how best to train students and working professionals in the STEM fields, particularly social science. The project tests a pedagogical approach that has been successful in other areas, namely, modular "nano" classes that are focused on experiential learning based on specific social problems and feature peer-to-peer learning between persons in the social sciences and computer science. Because the projects and problems to be worked on within the nano classes are designed together with federal, state, and local agencies, students will have the opportunity test and showcase their knowledge to current and future employers. The effectiveness of the program is evaluated by analyzing the reactions of the participants to the material provided, learning outcomes in terms of improved qualifications, use of learned material in their respective jobs, effects upon job performance, and estimates of rate of return. The data curation, management, interrogation and integration tools are built into a data facility system, within which collaboration is fostered, and which can be replicated and used by other curriculum adopters. A series of small randomized experiments will allow the empirical test of learning modules and improve them based on the results. The overall result of the project can be adapted by institutions in the US, and a program of outreach activities with the institution's international partners will allow an even broader transfer.

The NSF Research Traineeship (NRT) Program is designed to encourage the development and implementation of bold, new potentially transformative models for STEM graduate education training. The Innovations in Graduate Education Track is dedicated solely to piloting, testing, and evaluating novel, innovative, and potentially transformative approaches to graduate education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From education to health to criminal justice, government regulation and policy decisions have important effects on social and individual experiences. New data science tools applied to data created by government agencies have the potential to enhance these meaningful decisions. To overcome institutional barriers limiting the realization of this potential, the project created an innovate graduate education program that included both graduate students and government employees.

The program—which trains students and government employees on how to perform applied data analysis with confidential individual-level data generated through administrative processes, and extensive project-focused work—provides both online and onsite training components. Training takes place in a secure environment. The aim is to help agencies tackle important policy problems by using modern computational and data analysis methods and tools, while drawing on the academic insights from graduate students. The program accelerates the technical and analytical development of the participants and demonstrates the potential value of working with individual-level data across agency and jurisdictional lines. The initial success is being expanded through the creation of a larger community of academic institutions, government agencies, and foundations that can work together to increase the information infrastructure for society.

The program had three primary components:

  1. Technical (Computational and Data) Infrastructure with access to confidential agency microdata in a secure computing environment;
  2. Training Curriculum including lectures, hands-on sessions, and code notebooks using data and problems from multiple jurisdictions across policy areas;
  3. Collaborative Projects based on the needs of government agencies to seed new products.

Participants in the training program worked in a secure cloud-based environment and were introduced to new ways of collecting data and analyzing it using new computational and data analysis methods and tools. The overarching approach included training in how to keep fundamental statistical concepts like population frames, sampling, and valid inference while include modern computational data analysis tools, such as machine learning. Participants were also trained in the use of new types of data, including administrative data (records generated from the administration of government programs), data captured from websites or through application programming interfaces (APIs), and data with large spatial components, network structures, or text. The program is built on a foundation of social science research principles integrated with current analytic and computational skills, while being rooted in the study of real-world social and economic problem.

The materials are widely available.  The training materials are freely available in a textbook, which is now in its 2nd edition and available for anyone to read online. The syllabus and associated online videos are also available for broader use and adoption.   All the code is posted on github and can be reused by the broader data science community.

Since its inception, over 650 individuals have participated and been trained in data science basics. Many of those participants subsequently trained others in how to think and use data for evidence-based policy making and how to increase societal data infrastructure. Most notably, the program has helped inform the design of the federal data learning agenda.

The approach and associated material has been adopted and used in classes throughout the country in different disciplines: public policy, sociology, education, criminal justice, statistics, and economics. It has also created new federal and state capacity to tackle critical policy problems, ranging from improving understanding for human services providers about how to increase economic self-sufficiency for welfare recipients, to informing workforce boards about the characteristics of unemployment claimants to speed reemployment policy,  from using data to better target child nutrition policy, to building multistate dashboards that show state decision-makers about the links between educational investments and workforce outcomes. Finally, because the approach will be adopted by Historically Black Colleges and Universities and Hispanic Serving Institutions, the effects on building capacity for faculty training underrepresented minorities will continue for years to come.
